title: Future of rem | Cross-platform GUI in Rust in 2024?
description:
I recently made a project that got a little popularity, but it was in swift specifically for Apple Silicon.

A lot of people reached out to tell me i should make a cross platform version.

So i built the basics in rust, but I‚Äôm not positive where we are with GUI these days.

I‚Äôm kind of dreading complicating the app with front end tech / different web views etc (eg tauri) but it does come with a lot of useful stuff like automatic updates, tray icon, i know css etc.

The other GUI libraries i know about are iced and egui. But I‚Äôm really hoping i can get things to look quite polished, and i don‚Äôt have any good examples of well styled apps with iced/egui.

Anyway would love opinions from you all, and obviously would absolutely love any contributions!

Rust / Cross platform app: https://github.com/jasonjmcghee/xrem

Original app: https://github.com/jasonjmcghee/rem
description_plain:
I recently made a project that got a little popularity, but it was in swift specifically for Apple Silicon.

A lot of people reached out to tell me i should make a cross platform version.

So i built the basics in rust, but I‚Äôm not positive where we are with GUI these days.

I‚Äôm kind of dreading complicating the app with front end tech / different web views etc (eg tauri) but it does come with a lot of useful stuff like automatic updates, tray icon, i know css etc.

The other GUI libraries i know about are iced and egui. But I‚Äôm really hoping i can get things to look quite polished, and i don‚Äôt have any good examples of well styled apps with iced/egui.

Anyway would love opinions from you all, and obviously would absolutely love any contributions!

Rust / Cross platform app: https://github.com/jasonjmcghee/xrem

Original app: https://github.com/jasonjmcghee/rem

submitter_user.about:
https://jason.today

I spend time on full-stack web apps, machine learning, UX, design, product, solving problems, and communicating ideas. I've written patents, blog posts, and a whole lot of documentation and project specs. I like prototyping new ideas, and I've co-founded a startup with a successful exit, and working on the next. I consistently spend my time learning as much as I can.

I also dabble in game development, which generally took the form of C# and glsl, but in the last few years, it pushed me to pickup Rust, which has been a lot of fun.
